did.abstract: Lawyer and University of Michigan administrator with positions as director of the Office of Affirmative Action, policy advisor to the president, university freedom of information officer, associate vice-president for government relations and associate vice-president for student affairs. Series include policy coordinator/affirmative action, topical files, personal files, and photographs; include files relating to the formulation of the university's student discriminatory policy, 1988-1989, and to her work as consultant to the Michigan Women's Task Force on Rape, 1974-1980.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The Nordby papers were received in two accessions in 1992 and an additional accession in 1993 (Donor No. 8080).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Virginia Nordby papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Virginia Blomer was born in Chicago, Illinois in 1929. After matriculating at Stanford University, she graduated with distinction receiving a BA in English literature in 1951. As an undergraduate she also studied American history, philosophy and French. Three years later she received a J.D. from the Stanford School of Law. During her years at Stanford, she sat on the Board of Editors of the Stanford Law Review, serving as Article and Book Review Editor during her second and third years. Between her second and third years of law school Blomer married Gordon L. Nordby.

After serving as a research assistant for a University of Michigan law professor during the 1960's, Nordby became a lecturer in the School of Law in 1973, where she developed a course on women and the law. Also at this time, she became a consultant to the Michigan Women's Task Force on Rape. In this capacity she was the principal drafter of the Michigan Criminal Sexual Conduct Act, Public Act 266, 1974.

In 1975 she became a policy advisor in the university's Office of the President, a position which she held until 1988. She also served as the university's director of Affirmative Action, beginning in 1980. Nordby was promoted to associate vice president for government relations in 1988. At the time of her appointment she was also named secretary of the University of Michigan and she began serving as the university's chief freedom of information officer. During this period she was actively involved in the formulation and implementation of the university's student code of conduct, parts of which were later declared unconstitutional. After three years in government relations, she became associate vice-president for student affairs. In 1991, Nordby was honored with induction into the Michigan Women's Hall of Fame. She retired from the university in 1993.

scopecontent.p: The Virginia Nordby Papers (1972-1992) document the professional activities of Virginia Nordby during her tenure as a University of Michigan administrator and Law School lecturer. The papers have been divided into three principal series: Policy Coordinator/Affirmative Action, Topical Files, and Professional Files.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Affirmative action programs--Michigan--Ann Arbor.
controlaccess.corpname: Michigan Women's Task Force on Rape.
controlaccess.subject: Rape.
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Affirmative Action Office.

scopecontent.p: The Policy Coordinator/Affirmative Action series (1.7 linear feet) contains materials created and collected by and for Nordby while she served as a policy advisor to the university's administration and as director of the university's Affirmative Action program. The series is arranged in the order in which it was originally kept by Nordby and her file folder headings have been retained. Although the headings might not indicate it, most of the materials pertain to proposed changes, additions and deletions to, and clarifications of, the Regent's Bylaws.

did.unittitle: Committee on Computer Policy and Utilization 1987-1990
University Committee on Privacy & Access to Information 1980

scopecontent.p: The second series, Topical Files (2.3 linear feet), is particularly rich and is arranged alphabetically. Included among the files is significant documentation of the university's student discriminatory policy, the so-called "Code of Conduct." There is a complete set of drafts of the policy as well as comments and background material. There is also a large volume of material that relates to the university's policies on program review and discontinuance, which document Nordby's concern for the insurance of due process during reviews of programs and schools. Of interest are those files relating to policy issues impacting on athletics and the enforcement of Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972. Additional files address the implementation of the University's Discriminatory Harassment Policy.

did.unittitle: Report of the Task Force on Faculty Grievance Procedures February 1983
Answers to Most Frequently Asked Questions 1988-1989

scopecontent.p: The Professional Files series (1.5 linear feet), arranged alphabetically, contains materials from Nordby's activity as a member of the Michigan Women's Commission as well as files derived from her research undertaken during the drafting of what would become Michigan Criminal Sexual Conduct Act.

did.unittitle: Michigan Women's Task Force on Rape 1974-1980

odd.p: (primarily relating to research underlying the Michigan Criminal Sexual Conduct Act)
